WITH, More Excellent rea≈øons of greater con≈øequence, deliuered to the Kings Maie≈øty to di≈ø≈øolue the two treaties both of the Match and the Pallatinate, and enter into Warre with the Spaniards.

WHEREVNTO IS ADIOYNED A WORTHY ORAtion Appropriated, vnto the mo≈øt Mighty and Illu≈øtrious Princes of Chri≈øtendome, wherein the right and lawfulne≈ø≈øe of the Netherlandi≈øh warre again≈øt Phillip King of Spayne is approued and demon≈øtrated.

div.head: MORE EXCELLENT REASONS OF GREATER CONSEQVENCE, DELIVERED TO THE Kings Maie≈øty, to di≈ø≈øolue the two Treaties, both of the Match, and the Pallatinate, and enter into Warre with the Spaniard.
div.p: FIRST it is to be ob≈øerved, that the State of Spaine, not content with tho≈øe ordinary proui≈øions for the exerci≈øe of the Romane Religion, by the Infanta, and her family, (which other Princes in like ca≈øe would haue demaunded, and which his Maie≈øty with great rea≈øon, might at the beginning of the Treaty haue conceived they would haue beene contented with: Haue with great vehemency (upon advantage of having the Princes Per≈øon in their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion) pre≈ø≈øed a generall conniuence for all his Maie≈øties ≈øubiects of the Romane Religion; to the great di≈øhonor of Almighty God, in the ≈øincerity of his ≈øeruice in this Realme, and to the great derogation of the Lawes of this Kingdome. And la≈øtly, to the great di≈øcouragement, and griefe of all his Maie≈øties well affected ≈øubiects, from who≈øe generall di≈øcontent they expect (as well appeareth) a con≈øequence of no ≈ømall mi≈øchiefe.
Secondly it is ob≈øerued, that during the continuance of this treatie, and by rea≈øon of the ≈øame Popi≈øh faction, haue exceedingly increa≈øed in this Realme, both in multitude and boldne≈ø≈øe.

And whereas they haue beene divided heretofore among≈øt them≈øelues into the part of the Ie≈øuites depending vpon Spaine, and the ≈øecular Prie≈øts otherwi≈øe, They are generally now ≈øtrongly vnited together depending no le≈ø≈øe vpon Spaine for temporall re≈øpects, then vpon Rome for ≈øpirituall.

And con≈øidering the hou≈øe of Au≈øtria hath beene alwayes a capitall enemy to our Religion to increa≈øe their owne greatne≈ø≈øe, by extirpiting the prote≈øtant party in all places where they can prevaile. It cannot but be of mo≈øt dangerous con≈øequence, to the ≈øafety of the King, and the Realme vnle≈ø≈øe remedy be prouided with ≈øpeede, for the abating of that party here at home, which cannot be during the time that the≈øe Treatt≈øe are on foote.

Thirdly, it is ob≈øerued, that by aduantage of the≈øe Treaties, and thereby keeping of his Maie≈øty in hope of a generall peace, they haue contrarily vnder the pretence of a≈ø≈øi≈øting the Emperour, oppre≈ø≈øed the Prote≈øtants party in mo≈øt parts of Chri≈øtendome, being the ancient Alies and confederates of this Crowne, to the endangering not onely of the whole State of the reformed Religion, but al≈øo of the Common ≈øafety of all the profe≈ø≈øors of the ≈øame.

Fourthly, during the time of the≈øe Treaties of loue with his Maie≈øty, they haue with all kind of ho≈øtility, ≈øet vpon his Maie≈øties ≈øonne in Law, the husband of his onely and mo≈øt Royall Daughter, inuadeing his Townes and Territories in all places, and infine di≈ø-inherited him with all that Royall Off-≈øpring of all his ancient Patrimoniall Honors and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, to the great di≈øhonor of his Maie≈øty, and extreame griefe of all his well affected Subiects. And now al≈øo at the la≈øt, when they ≈øhould come to make good the hope of re≈øtitution, they haue layd new grounds for endle≈ø≈øe delayes, and turned pretended difficulties into apparant impo≈ø≈øibilities, not forbearing al≈øo now to annexe as a Condition to the weake hope of their vncertaine and imperfect re≈øolutions. That the elde≈øt ≈øonne of the Count Pallatine, ≈øhould be brought vp in the Emperours Court: ≈øo re≈øtle≈ø≈øe are their de≈øires to worke the ouerthrow of Religion by all po≈ø≈øible devices.

La≈øtly, it is apparant how manifoldly from time to time, they haue deluded and abu≈øed his Maie≈øty with their Treaties, how ≈ømall re≈øpect they haue ≈øhewed to the Prince his Greatne≈ø≈øe and worth, what endignities they haue offered againe and againe, to his highne≈ø≈øe, by importuning him vpon all aduantages to for≈øake his Religion, contrary to the cu≈øtome of all Princes, and contrary to the ancient Lawes of Honor, and Ho≈øpitality, who ought to haue beene v≈øed there withall Princely freedome, and pre≈ø≈øed to nothing vnto which he was indi≈øpo≈øed, con≈øidering with what confidence (being ≈øo great a Prince) he had put him≈øelfe within their power, although it plea≈øed God to guide and fortefie ≈øo his Princely heart, that he con≈øtantly with≈øtood all their attempts, and ≈øtratagems, to his owne immortall honor, and to the vn≈øpeakeable comfort of the good people of his Fathers Kingdome; Wherevnto may be added their infinite aduantagiou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and endle≈ø≈øe delayes in their Treaties. And finally what di≈øhonor they haue obtruded vpon our Nation and Religion in inviting ≈øtill to new Treaties, and turning al to the aduantage of their owne particuler ends, being true to nothing but their owne grounded Maximes, with which neither the Match nor the re≈øtitution of the Pallatinate can po≈ø≈øibly con≈øi≈øt, but vppon ≈øuch termes as threaten to our State, an incurable mi≈øchiefe.

div.head: AN ORATION OR SPEECH OF THE RIGHT AND LAWFVLNES of the Netherlandi≈øh Warres again≈øt Phillip King of Spaine: Vnto the mo≈øt Mighty and Illu≈øtrious Princes of Chri≈øtendome.
div.p: GReat and Mighty are the Kingdoms in your po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, which extend far and wide, throughout all the world: but much more great, and farre more excellent are the vertues and knowledge, by which you hold, pre≈øerue and governe the ≈øame righteou≈øly, even to the vttermo≈øt extent of felicity.

In the meane time let me now intreat you, √¥ mo≈øt peaceful Princes, that you will heare me with a friendly and well-affected minde, the ≈øequell hereof, and fundamentally will under≈øtand wherefore the Spaniards doe mo≈øt fal≈øely accu≈øe vs; That this peace was violated and broken by vs: which accu≈øation I hold to be very grievous.

Among other Conditions, Lawes, and Contracts of this peace, this was one of the chiefe≈øt and weightie≈øt: That Don Iohn ≈øhould not admit any Spaniard or ≈øtranger, nor any of them; by who≈øe coun≈øell and advi≈øe it was evidently knowne, that the Provinces were brought into that extreme ≈øpoyle, into the Councell: And contrarily,
hee called, and ≈øent for them to him, kept them in his Court, and in his mo≈øt ≈øecret chambers; That Bapti≈øta Taxis, a mo≈øt notable Spie, and enemy of our common affaires, who a little before had beene Secretary vnto Duke d' Alva, who was not onely adioyned to his priuy Coun≈øell, but al≈øo was made and ≈øet ouer them. Be≈øides him one Octauius Gonzago an Italian, as al≈øo hee tooke vnto him one E≈øcouedo, a crafty Spani≈øh Fox, vnto whom hee adioyned certaine Netherlanders. But what Netherlanders I pray you? Tho≈øe who partly had beene the ≈øtirrers vp and fauourers of ≈øo many mi≈øeries; who were both hated of their natiue Countrey, and of all good men; viz. Barlemont, Megan, Hierge, Flojon, Hautepenny, A≈ø≈øonuille, and other plagues of their Countrey, who hauing ordained the Law of Lentulus, Cataline and Ca≈ø≈øius, e≈øtabli≈øhed the ≈øame with their coun≈øels & deeds, viz. That all tho≈øe that by pre≈øeruing the Common-wealth would be pre≈øerued, ≈øhould be declared for enemies.

By this coun≈øell and aduice, the Spaniards pre≈øently, euen at the beginning of this peace, ≈øhould haue ≈øurprized the Towne of Gent, if the good and profitable coun≈øell, and al≈øo the valiant deeds of the States, had not hindred the ≈øame; For don Iohn him≈øelfe could not refraine nor keep in his hatred and enmity any longer, which he bore to the Netherlanders, but had quickly forgot that ≈øacred oath, which he had ≈øworne, vpon the Euangeli≈øts, before the Bi≈øhop of Shertogenbo≈øeh, and the Popes Nuncius, or ≈øpirituall Emba≈ø≈øadour.

He had promi≈øed and ≈øworn; that hee would deale with all the ≈øouldiers in the Netherlands, who were 15000, about their Arrearages, to the end, that they thereupon might bee di≈øcharged, like as in the agreement of the peace had beene concluded. And contrarily thereunto, he promi≈øed the Souldiers, in the Kings behalfe, anew, to haue greater meanes, honours, offices and rewards: and held a mo≈øt mi≈øchieuous coun≈øel with Fron≈øberghen and Focker, Collonels of the German ≈øouldiers; part of who≈øe wicked coun≈øell hee effected, and the re≈øt being hindred by the States he could not effect.

But yet to the end, that you may ≈øee and know the ground of this Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, I will in few words declare vnto you how the matter fell out: For vnder the≈øe two conditions or couenants, viz. in maintaining of the Romi≈øh Religion; and in yeelding lawfull obedience to the King, did the whole Treatie of the peace con≈øi≈øt.

And when the States which had ≈øworne hereunto with an high Oath, then were they pre≈øently admitted, that tho≈øe affaires concerning the Land, which pre≈øently in the beginning of the treatie of peace were begunne, but could not be concluded vpon, that they ≈øhould be di≈øpatched and concluded in the next a≈ø≈øembly of the States.

But yet Don Iohn, who≈øe affection burned with a lu≈øt and longing de≈øire, by ≈øome ≈øecret and concealed practice to breake the peace, and to begin the warre againe, ca≈øting all the≈øe conditions and promi≈øes at his heeles, made a way for tho≈øe complaints which Phillip, and all the former Governours had v≈øed as a cloake to cover all their intended w ‚Ä¢ cked imgainations again≈øt the Rei-publicke, viz. That the Hollanders and Sealanders neglected and de≈øpi≈øed the Romi≈øh Religion; and by that meanes the commandement of the King was neglected.

Vpon this Anvile did they hammer night and day? they a≈ø≈øayled the States, and were exceeding trouble≈øome vnto them, coun≈øelling them that they altogether ≈øhould beginne the warres, again≈øt Holland, Sealand, and the Prince of Orange, who was the mo≈øt eminent Champion again≈øt the vniu≈øt government of the Spaniards, who indeede had beene exceeding beneficiall to the whole Common-wealth.

In this coun≈øell Don Iohn had his eye vpon the≈øe two obiects, which ≈øhould be exceeding profitable and ≈øerviceable to further his intent; that by their Ciuill warres, the ≈øub≈øtance and trea≈øure of the land might be exhau≈øted, and they being weakned and bruy≈øed by their owne Warre, that then he, with the more ea≈øe and conveniency might ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe them together.

Whereas he ≈øtill per≈øi≈øting with the≈øe de≈øires and intreaties, being as it were da≈øht again≈øt a Rocke by a Tempe≈øt: The States an≈øwered him; that it were better and more profitable for the Common-wealth, That concerning all tho≈øe matters whereof Don Iohn made his complaints, to haue them by a friendly compo≈øition decided, and vnited, in the a≈ø≈øembly of the States; and if they could haue imprinted or per≈øwaded him to haue beleeued the ≈øame, we had never fallen into the mi≈øeries of a Ciuill Warre.

For what is more repugnant to the common good, and to all humane Lawes and Iu≈øtice; then to try by warre, tho≈øe controver≈øies,
which may be decyded by Right and Rea≈øon. Arch ‚Ä¢ damus (though no Chri≈øtian King, but of a ≈øtately, honourable any provident Nation) ≈øayd; That it was vnlawfull to take Armes again≈øt tho≈øe, who were willing to haue the matter tryed by Law. When and iniury had beene offered to the Romanes them≈øelues; they did not pre≈øently begin with wars: but did fir≈øt ≈øend Clarigatum, that is, they cau≈øed tho≈øe things that were ≈øtollen or taken away, to be more apparently and manife≈øtly demanded againe.

But how profitable, good, and wel-ordred is the cum≈øtome of the Common-wealth of the Venetians, which I lately ≈øaw and ob≈øerved; where they will not ≈øuffer that the principall Nobles them≈øelues of that flouri≈øhing Common-wealth, ≈øhould contend, chide, or maintaine enmity among them≈øelues, for, or about other mens ≈ømall and petty affaires. But they bring the ≈øame into their Senate, or Councell, and there they de≈øire, pray, and admoni≈øh them, that they will remember, and be mindfull, that they are all of them Saint Markes children (which name they haue given their Rei-publicke) and that they are brethren, and Burge≈øes of ≈øuch a free and happy government, and that it was not be≈øeeming for them, for any particular bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, to cheri≈øh and fo≈øter any private di≈ø≈øention or hatred, which might thereafter prooue to be more generall, to the perill and danger of that Rei-publicke.

Which cu≈øtome aboue all other affaires ought to be v≈øed in the affaires concerning the Land, and ought to be e≈øteemed of in all wel-ordered Common-wealths. If this were ≈øo, we ≈øhould not ≈øee one City ≈øo again≈øt another (oftentimes in one Province or Rei-publicke) or one Noble-man ≈øo again≈øt another of the contrary party, to threaten warre, murther, de≈øtruction, burning and blaking, nor violence to a≈ø≈øault each other.

But now to returne to our former purpo≈øe, in re≈øpect that there are two ≈øorts of Warres: the one with words by way of Iu≈øtice; the other with violence. The fir≈øt being proper to men, the ≈øecond to vnrea≈øonable bea≈øts. And that wee mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily avoyde violence, vnle≈ø≈øe the cour≈øe of Iu≈øtice be denyed vs. Therefore we mu≈øt beleeue that the States farre rather would haue decyded tho≈øe controver≈øies, by their good and whole≈øome coun≈øels, by rea≈øon and conference; then to make them greater by Warre and ≈øpilling the
blood of the Citizens. Contrarily Don Iohn complaineth of the States very publiquely: Hee reprooues and vpbraids them all for Rebels, and then deales with the High-dutch Souldiers no longer by ≈øecret dealing in the affaires very prejudiciall to the Common-wealth (with whom very cunningly hee had long time dealt with all) but then began he very publickly to deale with them; ≈øo that the whole di≈øcovery of that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, by divers intercepted letters, was fully come to the knowledge of the States. And many things they dayly ≈øaw with their eyes, as fir≈øt when he removed his Court and family, with his Councell-companions to Bergen in Henegow (being a very ≈øtrong Towne, and very fit for his conjurations and complottings) and commanded that the ≈øame ≈øhould bee provided with a ≈øtrong Garri≈øon.

Moreover, when as he ≈øurprized the Ca≈øtle of Antwerpe by Treacherie, and did ≈øurprize tho≈øe well provided and fortified Townes of Namen and Charlemont, and put a ≈øtrong guard into them of his owne ≈øouldiers, thinking thereafter by treachery to haue taken in the Towne of Bru≈ø≈øels, So that already the principall and chiefe Cities and Townes, by the great number of his Forts and Citadels, where beleagred and oppre≈ø≈øed; and then he wholly beganne to ≈øet vp him≈øelfe again≈øt the Rei-publick; and al≈øo many other things were then done by his advi≈øe and motion: whereas hee according to his oath, ought to haue advi≈øed, that all the ≈øouldiers ≈øhould haue layd downe their Armes, and pre≈øently to haue departed out of the Country.

All which things appearing manife≈øtly to the eyes of the States, who adjudged that the ≈øame tented to the ≈øubver≈øion of the Common-wealth; they thought that they were bound continually to keepe a good coun≈øel-watch; neither did they turne their eyes a≈øide from the Rei-publick, from that time that he ≈øought to haue all the governement alone, vnto whom they in all officiou≈øne≈ø≈øe (not being mooved by any di≈øtemperature of minde) ≈øent as Emba≈ø≈øadours vnto him, Marolaus and Bru≈øus, charging them that they ≈øhould pre≈øent and ≈øhew, their full performance, innocency, and integrity, and ≈øhould free them from all ≈øu≈øpition and evill conceit, (the which they mo≈øt certainly knew, that he mi≈øchievou≈øly had di≈ø≈øembled,) that the faith that was given at Gent ≈øhould be renued: They ≈øhould al≈øo promi≈øe, that the States ≈øhould make diligent enquirie, and execute
≈øeuere puni≈øhment vppon tho≈øe Treacherous murtherers and con≈øpirators, who (as he ≈øayd) layd waite for his life, and had con≈øpired again≈øt him; (making a ≈øhewe and di≈ø≈øembling, as if to prevent the ≈øame, hee went to Namen:) They would augment his Guard more then tho≈øe he had already, to the number of three hundred compleat armed men, who ≈øhould bee all of them Netherlanders, the which before that time was never offered to any Governour or Ruler. And yet with all the≈øe ≈øupplications and intreaties they effected nothing; for there was neither mode≈øty nor rea≈øon to be found in Don Iohn. Nay, hee could not bridle nor keepe in his owne evill arrogancy and audacious pa≈ø≈øion; but declared the ≈øame to Marollaus at the ≈øame time of his Emba≈ø≈øage, boa≈øting him≈øelfe, that hee now did wholly a≈ø≈øure him≈øelfe, and that hee doubted not, but that hee had brought vnder the ≈øubjection of his will and command, the Citie of Antwerpe, that hee had no lacke neither of money nor men; that hee now had all things in a readine≈ø≈øe, for the furni≈øhing of a Warre; and that hee with his ≈øword, would purcha≈øe vnto him≈øelfe a greater authority, power, command and government; then the States had promi≈øed and granted him in the pacification of Gent; and that it was his will, that the≈øe Emba≈ø≈øadours ≈øhould report all the≈øe things vnto the States, for he would not conceale any thing from them that hee knew to appertaine to this his intent and will. This matter is undoubtedly ≈øure and certaine, and ≈øufficiently knowne before this, ≈øo that heere it is not needefull to produce witne≈ø≈øes. And although it be a very mi≈øerable thing, not to be able to deny, and very ≈øhamefull to be confe≈øt; yet I thinke verily that the Spaniards them≈øelues (although they be le≈ø≈øe ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe then a man would beleeue they are) cannot deny this at any time. Is he yet ignorant, that the coun≈øels of all our people, with a generall con≈øent and vniformity of voices, are long agoe vnited and knit fa≈øt together in this point; and that they will farre rather honourably in warre and Armes liue and die, for their Lawes, and for their natiue Country; then from henceforth ≈øhamefully to ≈øinke or quaile, vnder his treacheries and deceits? What, doe I ≈øay ≈øinke or quaile? Nay, to come into the extreame≈øt euills of Tyrannie; to bee bound with vntolerable and inhamane bonds of ≈ølauerie, and to bee reckoned and accounted among tho≈øe ≈ølaues that are bought and ≈øould. We haue prepared, made ready and ≈øharpened, a perpetuall and an euerla≈øting warre and Armes again≈øt him: we neither haue, nor may ca≈øt our eyes vpon any other peace, then vpon ≈øuch a peace as is grounded, confirmed, and may bee maintained with force and Armes.

But in regard that a little before I beganne to ≈øpeak of France, and to proue that our warre partly was joyned with that ≈øame; therfore I will proceede to adde ≈øome other matters hereunto, by the which you may evidently ≈øee and perceiue, how many treacheries, traps and deceits that Phillip hath laid for them.

He hath a long time ≈øince, as you know, O Princes, laboured and endeuored to a≈ø≈øaile France, with all the violence and force of his warre; to the end that he by the occa≈øion of the Civill di≈ø≈øentions in France, might effect ≈øo much by his wars and charges: that if he could not ≈øwallow and devoure the whole Kingdome; yet that at the lea≈øt he might get a great part thereof. For he had made his full reckoning and accovnt before hand, by preparing of that cruell
Fleet, that both France and England had been a prey vnto their enemies: Wheras tho≈øe good Princes, notwith≈øtanding had nothing at all endamaged him, neither was he by any juiu≈øtice provoked to that warre; vnle≈ø≈øe peradventure it be, that he thought this occa≈øion ≈øufficient; that the Pope, at the will and de≈øire of Phillip had excommunicated tho≈øe two flouri≈øhing Kingdoms, for their exerci≈øing and mini≈øtery of the Reformed Religion; who for the extirpation and eradication of that Religion; Phillip as a Cato Maior, with the pui≈ø≈øance of the Romi≈øh Cen≈øores (or correction ma≈øters) v≈øeth to haue regard vnto all the Kings and people of the earth, and therefore to correct and puni≈øh them, which is indeede a matter known vnto you all; for which no man can ≈øufficiently wonder at the ≈øhamefulne≈ø≈øe thereof, and might now neither be pa≈ø≈øed by nor omitted. And that Phillip in the≈øe warres of France dealt mo≈øt earne≈øtly, and with the greate≈øt diligence and alacrity, with the Duke of Feres, and other Spaniards of the League, whom he as companions, had a≈ø≈øi≈øted in that warre, to haue e≈øtranged the Right and Title of the Crowne of France, not onely from the ≈øucce≈ø≈øion or de≈øcent of the Kings blood and kinred, but euen from all Frenchmen, and to haue drawne the ≈øame to Spaine.

The≈øe things are ≈øo certaine, O Princes, that there is no man which doubteth of the truth hereof. But to what end do I bring the≈øe into your Remembrances; What is this to maintaine the purpo≈øe I haue in hand; For this end it ≈øerueth; thereby to proue how exceeding great the ambition is of this mo≈øt cruell Tyrant; and to the end you may perceiue and ≈øee how greatly, not onely we, but euen all of you together, mu≈øt keep good watch and looke vnto it. For like as the nature of the Vine, is to extend the branches, as the armes thereof farre and wide, and therewith embraceth and layeth hold vpon euery thing that is neer it, if it be not lopt and pruned; Euen ≈øo ≈øhall Phillip, if you doe not all at once make re≈øi≈øtance, at the la≈øt de≈øtroy and devoure all Chri≈øtendom, with mo≈øt cruell and bloody warre.

Moreover, he by his Btibery, and ≈øecret con≈øpiracy had lately effected ≈øo much in Scotland, that ≈øome of the chiefe of that Kingdome, ≈øhould haue received and taken in twenty thou≈øand Spaniards, if they had not been puni≈øhed (after the matter was knowne and revealed) according as their trea≈øon de≈øerued. I need not to thinke
with my ≈øelfe, that I can ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øe with words, what trea≈øons, what perills, what daungers, he, ≈øo oftentimes hath attempted again≈øt the Queene and Kingdome of England. Can ambition and violence proceed yet any further? Yes truely, For the like treacheries practi≈øed hee a little before again≈øt the Principallity of Collen, the Dukedomes of Gelders, Gulich, Cleane; the County of Berghe, and that ancient Emperiall Towne of Aken: All which is mo≈øt manife≈øtly and apparantly knowne by good Te≈øtimony, and by his owne letters. And who knoweth in what lurking hole and corner of hipocri≈øie and di≈ø≈øimulation, he hideth and ≈øheltreth his mo≈øt mortall hate again≈øt the mo≈øt mighty Princes of Italy; whom (as ≈øoone as the wind of the fir≈øt oportunity ≈øhall blow (very ≈øuddenly, ≈øhall be turned into coales and a≈øhes, by his vnquenchable and fearefull great flames of Warre.

Doe ye not yet ≈øee and perceiue enough, √¥ Princes, what treacheries and deceits that Philip prepareth, for your mo≈øt happy Kingdomes and Prouinces, which are your Patrimonies? Con≈øidering there is no man ≈øo blind nor ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe, who ≈øeeth not, and vnder≈øtandeth not that the ambition of Phillip neuer re≈øteth, but dayly draweth him from land to land, and rai≈øeth a new warre out of war; So that he by warres, ≈øinne, mi≈øchiefe, and meere villanous deceits and treacheries, vnder the pretence of a ≈øeeming-peace, ≈øeeketh to deject and detrude euery one of you from the ≈øeate of your Gouernment. For this his de≈øire is vn≈øatiable and immoderate, and cannot be included nor ≈øhut vp, neither in Heauen nor in Earth. If that all Phillips Kingdomes which he u≈øeth commonly in that long traine or taile of his mo≈øt proud Titles and Termes of Honour were put or layd into one of the Seales of Critolaes ballance, and in his other ≈øeale his Ambition or greedie de≈øire of Honour; All the Kingdomes would ≈øcarcely weigh the quantity of one graine, in compari≈øon of his Ambition.

Alexander the Great looked about for more worlds, when he had conquered the whole world; but Phillip would, if he could, with the Gyants a≈ø≈øault the heauens. And therefore, O Princes, and you mo≈øt peacefull Princes, I intreate you, and I would admoni≈øh you, that you judge no more of the occa≈øion and lawfulne≈ø≈øe of our warre; but in your judgements and opinions to hold it for good: and I exhort you mo≈øt earne≈øtly againe and againe, that you by all
meanes, both in your vnder≈øtandings, and with all your powers, will take heed of the treacheries, robberies, and mi≈øchievous practi≈øes of Phillips deceit.

In former times, whenas the Athenians, partly with warre, and partly with deceits and treacheries, ≈øought to get unto them≈øelues certaine neere adjacent places, as the Cities of Syracu≈øa, Lacaedemon, Me≈ø≈øena and Catina: they by their immoderate Ambition, and de≈øire of others Rights, drewe ≈øuch an hatred upon their owne heads, that Darius the mo≈øt mighty King of Per≈øia, with the whole country of Grecia, voluntarily undertooke and pro≈øecuted warre again≈øt them, unto which euery man ranne and ha≈øted, as to quench a publicke flame. But you, O mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious Princes, ought long ago to haue expelled Phillip, (with your conjoyned forces from you, and from your pro≈øperous States) that ≈øeeketh continually your liues and Kingdomes, by mo≈øt unju≈øt warre, and by mo≈øt wicked enterpri≈øes.

And it concernes, and is fitting, not onely for you, who for a long time ≈øince, haue beene provoked, ≈øpurred, and ≈øtirred up thereunto, by the many injuries and ambition of Phillip, but euen you altogether, who ≈øee and perceiue, that he incroacheth with violence upon the limmits of your neighbours; and with an ea≈øie and ≈ølow pace creepeth and incroacheth towards your Countries. It ≈øtandeth you upon in time to looke unto it; to the end, that your neighbouring Countries, being conquered and brought under his ≈ølauery and bondage, Tyranny, when you le≈øt thinke upon it, do not incroach upon you.

When as Phillip of Macedon, the Father of Alexander the Great, after the Battell with the Tribaldes, had entertained a long di≈ø≈øembling warre with the Athenians, the Thebeans a≈ø≈øembled them≈øelues for this occa≈øion; fearing, le≈øt when the Athenians had bene conquered, the fire of their neighbouring-warre might haue flowne unto them. And a little before, there being a confederacy made betwixt two of the mightie≈øt Cities; who, before had bene at extreme enmity with each other, terrified thereby, and by their Emba≈ø≈øadors, all the Country of Grecia: e≈øteeming it ≈øo, that a common enemy ought and mu≈øt be repelled with common force; ≈øo that if the fir≈øt inva≈øion of Phillip of Macedon, had had good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe; he would not haue held up, nor re≈øted untill he had conquered and ≈øubjugated the
whole country of Grecia. The Romanes in former time, perceauing that the power of the Carthaginians increa≈øed and grew great, they had an e≈øpecial care that the Carthagenians ≈øhould not grow ≈øo great as to ouer-ma≈øter them: And for that end they ≈øent their ≈øouldiers to relieue the Mamertines from the beleagring, and to relieue Spain from ≈øeruitude of the Africans.

Although that the Venetians are not very lightly incited to warre, but when the matter of nece≈ø≈øity con≈øtrayneth them: Yet they neuer tefu≈øed to ≈øend their warlike power for the ≈øuccour of others that were under them, when they perceaued that their neighbours contended with each other, with an vnrea≈øonable and an immoderate violent ambitione.

The≈øe, and the like even to an innumirable examples (or foredeedes) doe teach you, how carefully you mu≈øt take heede of that mo≈øt pe≈øtilent evill, of the Spani≈øh ambition; and do ≈øhew; or proue, that it is a righteous and ju≈øt cau≈øe, that even all you with one con≈øent with us, pro≈øecute a warre again≈øt that Tyrant.

For our States do know, that the occa≈øion of their warre again≈øt Phillip, is not onely exceeding ju≈øt and righteous, and ever was: but al≈øo, that they at no time, now nor never, may cea≈øe their warre, that they may make no peace with Phillip, but alwayes mu≈øt mainetaine warre again≈øt that Tyrant. For we are taught by our friends, how we mu≈øt take heed of our enemies: For if Phillip do gape and long ≈øo earne≈øtly, and with ≈øuch diligence for your Kingdomes; like as you ≈øee he daily doth; how then ≈øhall we ≈øpeed? For a≈ø≈øuredly he wil never lay a≈øide Armes before that he hath ≈øubjugated all the Netherlands under him, becau≈øe it is a Countrey ≈øo fit for his purpo≈øe; who, out of them may attempt many enterpri≈øes upon your Kingdomes, and dayly may beginne to rai≈øe new warres again≈øt you, and draw out of them Souldiers, Armes, and all manner of warlike provi≈øion again≈øt your adjacent Countries. And therefore he would farre rather ca≈øt the greate≈øt part of Chri≈øtendome for a prey to the Turke; then to cea≈øe the≈øe warres.

At the la≈øt Parliament in Germany, he would not con≈øent to furni≈øh the Emperor with any ≈øoldiers, nor a≈ø≈øi≈øtance again≈øt the Turke; and the rea≈øon was, becau≈øe he might the better vexe Chri≈øtendome with warre.

Doe yee yet doubt of this, O yee Princes, which you your ≈øelues
haue ≈øeene, that Phillip in the beginning of our ciuill commotions, had far rather loo≈øe two Kingdoms, Tunis and Goulet, which the Turkes, under their General Sinam Ba≈øcha then recouered from him, then that hee would for a while cea≈øe his warres with us; or would remoue his Souldiers out of the≈øe Prouinces, again≈øt the mo≈øt deadly and mortal enemy of all Chri≈øtendome.

And you know how many Souldiers, how much Armes, and what charges Phillip hath been at, and wa≈øted, to maintain this war again≈øt us. So that if you would but reckon up the ≈øame, you ≈øhall find that he might haue bought and purcha≈øed two Netherlands with that mony: although notwith≈øtanding they be very great, rich, and exceeding copious. So that there is no doubte of this, but Phillip would far rather endure the greate≈øt lo≈ø≈øe that might betide him then that he would leaue Bellgium with out bellum, or the Low-countries without long encountrings of warre, with out ≈øtrife, without ≈øouldiers, that they might liue in peace and quietne≈ø≈øe, freely and wholy according to their Lawes and priuiledges. For by this war, and with the conque≈øt of our Prouinces, he wil lay and e≈øtabli≈øh the ≈øtronge≈øt foundation and ≈øure≈øt ground-worke of his Monarchy, Sole-dominion, Tyrannie, and cruel Gouernment. For when he ≈øaw and perceaued that the≈øe Countries were ≈øo ≈øingularly fitting for his cruel treacheries and de≈øgnments, and that our Lawes and Liberties contraryly did wholy oppo≈øe the ≈øame: therfore ≈øought he fir≈øt of all with warre, with force and violence, to plucke vp, teare in ≈øunder, and with violence, to oppre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame, to the end, that his ≈øubiects of other Kingdoms, which at this pre≈øent he hath ≈øubiugated, or el≈øe might ≈øubiugate hereafter; from this our concording, and generall defence of our Lawes and Liberty, might take no example or in≈øtance, with the greater courage and alacrity, to ≈øtand for, and maintaine their liberty.

What do you then iudge, √¥ you mo≈øt peaceful Princes? or what is your conclu≈øion that our States ought to doe, who chiefly ≈øeek for the common good of their natiue Countrey? Verily it cannot be with them, as it is vnder the Gouernment of a cruel Tirant, and as it u≈øually is in ill-gouerned Reipublicks: they are not v≈øed to be lead, and to ≈øubmit them≈øelues at any time, with cap and knee, as flatterers doe? to the wills, de≈øires, and lu≈øts of their ≈øuperiour Lords, nor to be dealt with all as hired ≈ølaues? con≈øidering that
they neuer would admit nor ≈øuffer, that their Lawes, Liberties, nor their Reipublick, ≈øhould bow or ≈øubmit vnder the yoake of vniu≈øt and vnlawfull Government: But haue as good fathers of their natiue-Countrey; as good fighters for their freedome, and Defendors of their Lawes, (like as it mu≈øt be in a Reipublick which is moderately and ciuilly gouerned by their Prince) directed their de≈øignes, wils, and gouernment of their ≈øuperiour Lord; according to their Lawes, and the pre≈øeruation of their Liberty.

Do you think that the Spaniards ≈øhall ≈øpoyle and cruell vexe and torment our Reipublick; and that we with ≈øhame will leaue and quit the ≈øame? Shall we neglect our deare countrey and liberty? Mu≈øt we de≈øpi≈øe the lawes of our predece≈ø≈øors? And ≈øhall they peruert & turn top≈øie-turvie our ciuill orders and policy into tyranny? And ≈øhall we with wringing hands look vpon the coar≈øe, and behold the exequies or funerall of our patria and natiue countrey? Shal they rend & teare in peeces the body of our common-wealth, and like mo≈øt ravenous bea≈øts deuoure the ≈øame? And ≈øhall we like ≈ølaues, with praying and intreating, hardly pre≈øerue our own liues, goods, and meanes? Or do ye not far rather laud & extol with the highe≈øt commendation of honour, this will and affection of our States, for their manumi≈øing and pre≈øeruing of their deare and natiue countrey? Incite and exhort you them to proceed as they are be≈øt able, and to the vttermo≈øt of their powers, for the pre≈øervation and manumi≈øing of their owne liues and liberty? Come not the≈øe things daily into your remembrances, when you think of the Netherlandi≈øh warre, or di≈øcour≈øe thereof, which I haue now demon≈øtrated, and with ≈øure and infallible and vncontrollable rea≈øons proued vnto you, viz. that our States, & all the Netherlanders, being drenched and ≈øoaked in mi≈øery, and oppre≈ø≈øed with the cruelty of the Spaniards; and being expeld out of their natiue countrey, of meere nece≈ø≈øity were con≈øtrained to take Arms again≈øt Philip. And that now all the other treacheries, infidelities & iniuries which the Spaniards during the time of the≈øe wars haue done vnto the Netherlanders, being ≈øo great, ≈øo inhumane, and ≈øo incredible, that they them≈øelues (≈øo to ≈øpeak) do earne≈øtly exhort, do require & command, that the States with a con≈øtant courage, ≈øhould keepe and maintaine their armes, and neither now, nor neuer, to lay them out of their hands; but to ≈øhew vnto the other ≈øubiects of Phillip (tho≈øe of Sicilia,
Calabria, Lombardy, Arragon, Ca≈øtile, India, & Portugal) yea euen vnto your ≈øelues, O Illu≈øtrious Princes, I ≈øay to ≈øhew, and with valiant deeds to proue, that not onely we, but all of you together, yea and all men vpon the face of the earth, far rather ought to dye, then to behold or looke vpon the face of that tyrant.

Do ye yet think, or can you imagine with your ≈øelues, that Phillip, with the limits of our countrey, hath limited in his tyranny? Do yee not yet ≈øee and perceiue, that the high a≈øcending and mortall flames of the Spani≈øh tyranny, devoureth and ≈øwalloweth vp the tre≈øholds, doores, and turrets of your kingdomes? Ari≈øe, and at the la≈øt awake out of this your ≈øleepe and carele≈øne≈ø≈øe; come hither with ≈øpeede, and in all ha≈øte flye hereinto, for to quench the≈øe vniuer≈øall fireflames. Wherefore do yee ≈øeeke vnto vs again≈øt our wils, by your coun≈øels, authorities, and re≈øpects, to induce vs to make peace with Phillip; whereas it had been more fitting, that you your ≈øelues long agoe, with warre and force of armes ≈øhould haue expelled Philip, and with an e≈øpeciall force and power to haue ≈øuppre≈øt him?

And to the end I may ≈øpeake vnto you all one after another, you mo≈øt mighty Princes of Germany, be ≈øencible, that Philip in your Dutchland doth not hunt after a cruell and vniu≈øt government; but (≈øo to ≈øpeake) doth po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame already. For he hauing once conquered the≈øe Netherlandi≈øh prouinces; when you will not bow and ≈øubmit to his gouernment: he will haue all the hauens of the ≈øea, and the mouthes of all the Germane riuers at his owne will, and in his owne power: thereby afterwards to impo≈øe ≈øuch grieuous toles and taxations, vpon your nauigation and trading, or el≈øe wholly will hinder the ≈øame, euen as it ≈øhall plea≈øe him≈øelfe. And this is that for which, and in behalfe whereof, one or two of the prouinces doe appeare in your a≈ø≈øemblies and con≈øultations: you heare him publickly ≈øpeak his minde, and you e≈øteeme and preferre his tyrannicall advice and coun≈øell, before your owne pro≈øperity and tranquility. You haue him, the Bi≈øhop of Fri≈øinghen and Hilde≈øhem preferred before; and you haue ≈øeene them made Princes and Prince-Electors of the Empire; The Bi≈øhop of Collen, Liege, and Magdeborgh: and you haue ≈øeene that the mo≈øt ambitious Duke of Bavaria hath laid ≈ønares for you all.

And to the end that I may turne my ≈øpeech vnto you, O you illu≈øtrious & mighty powerful Princes of Poland, hath not Philip brought
a great number of that generation of mankind, (I ≈øay Ie≈øuites) into your Countrey, by who≈øe religion and policy they haue brought almo≈øt the whole world into an vp-rore, to the end that he by their meanes, with Sun-≈øhine-like deceits, might propound vnto you what his will and coun≈øell is.

To you al≈øo, mo≈øt peaceful Princes of Italy, I haue already ≈øayd, and ≈øay againe, that the ≈øword of the Spani≈øh tyranny hangeth by a very ≈ømall threed ouer your heads, already naked and drawne out of the ≈øcabberd.

And for you, O mo≈øt illu≈øtrious Senators (or Priuy Councellors) of Venice, you your ≈øelues haue ≈øeen and beheld the tyranny of Phillip in your owne State and gouernment, when he ≈øent money to arme the Turke again≈øt you; and diuerted the power and force of the Turk from his owne dominions vpon Cypris; although that hee by thee quity and right of the covenant, had been exceedingly oblieged and beholding vnto you.

Therefore O Princes of Christendome, yet euen now, at the longla≈øt, be carefull of your owne e≈øtates and affaires, of your owne liues and pro≈øperitie; marke and con≈øider it well, that Phillip is enemy and tyrant to you all, and ≈øuffer him to liue no longer in the world: but re≈øi≈øt and impeach his ambition to reigne, and that his pe≈øtilent and mortall government proceed no further. And like as ≈øome certaine members are cut off when they begin to be without life and blood, and are hurtfull to all the other parts of the body; euen ≈øo mu≈øt you al≈øo e≈øteeme, that this inhumane cruelty in humane ≈øhape, mu≈øt (≈øo to ≈øpeak) be ≈øeparated and cut from the common body of men. Verily the deed of the Per≈øians is much to be commended, and ought to be wel thought upon of you all; who when Cometes and Oropa≈øtes two of their Magicians (or wi≈øe men) by the like tyrannie and murther of Smerdis, King of Per≈øia, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Kingdom: they were ≈ølaine by the valour of ≈øeuen of the able≈øt Princes of Per≈øia, all of them running with a ≈øingular affection, diligence, and burning zeale to kill and to de≈øtroy tho≈øe tyrants with their ≈øwords, one of the Magitians cla≈øped about the neck of one of the Princes who≈øe name was Gebrias, which made his companions to linger the more, becau≈øe they would not kill him in ≈øteed of the Magician (for this was done in a dark place) who commanded the Magician to thru≈øt his ≈øword through his body. Yet in the end the Magician was ≈ølaine, and this
valiant Gebrias (who had rather to haue died, then that the tyrant ≈øhould haue e≈øcaped with life) was ≈øaved, and had his life pre≈øerved, Such an hate did the≈øe men beare to tyrants.

The Grecians informer times attributed divine honour to tho≈øe men who had ≈ølaine a tyrant, And doe you thinke that the Netherlanders ≈øhall do euill, or more vniu≈øt, that they oppo≈øe and re≈øi≈øt Philip that jnhumane tyrant.

The Romanes expelled their King Taquinus Superbus, becau≈øe that he, did but in ≈øome ≈øort weaken the ≈øtate of their common-wealth; and ≈øhall we ≈øuffer or indure Phillip in our common-wealth, who not onely with fire and ≈øword would de≈øtroy and turn-vp-≈øide-downe all the Netherlands, but euen the whole world? No, by no meanes. Our States without doubt, will proceede and prepare the way for you to break off, and to expel this tyrant. They wil per≈øeuere to diuert, driue away, and to foyle him ≈øo farre and wide from ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing and killing of our pro≈øperity, that once, not onely they and theirs, but al≈øo euen the other provinces of the Netherlands, may bere-e≈øtabli≈øhed in their former liberty, and may lead them out of the ≈øtraights of the Spani≈øh tyranny, and repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe them in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of their predece≈ø≈øors. That finally, they being re-e≈øtabli≈øhed, and better ordered, and vnited and bound with the Prouinces of the whole Netherlands; they may ≈øtop the incur≈øion and inva≈øion of this cruell tyrant, and altogether with one accord may expell him from their pro≈øperity, and from their common liberty. Amen.

GEntle Reader, there being ≈øo much ≈øpoken, as thou mai≈øt perceiue, by the fore-going fir≈øt Part of the Spani≈øh practi≈øes, touching the cruell, inhumane, trecherous, perfidious; yea, vnnaturall practi≈øes of the Spaniards, in mo≈øt parts of the World, which may ≈øufficiently delineate him in his de≈øerued colours, that who≈øoeuer beholds him may mourne to ≈øee this Hazael ≈øo to tyrannize ouer the innocent, and that the Lord ≈øhould permit, and the earth beare ≈øuch an vnheard of mon≈øter; yet notwith≈øtanding, much more might be added in ≈øundry other particulars, as the Dutch Chronicles mention, and other Writers haue well ≈øet out: among≈øt which, although I my ≈øelfe be a ≈øtranger by Nation to them; yet ≈øince the time of my abode here, hauing attained ≈øome vnder≈øtanding in the Language, I haue thought fit to adde ≈øome further particulars, which in my reading I haue ob≈øerued, and could adde many more; but my purpo≈øe being onely to annex a few things, I will not enlarge, le≈øt I adde another Treati≈øe. But before I come to what I intend, I haue thought fit hauing ≈øome ouer≈øight in the publi≈øhing of this Treati≈øe aforegoing, to note by the way, The Dutch word Ghe≈øante ≈øignifieth indifferently Emba≈ø≈øadour or Me≈ø≈øenger. the ill tran≈ølating of one word, in the 21 folio, it is touching the Prince≈ø≈øe of Parma, the Tran≈ølator termes her a crafty Queane, wheras the word beares no ≈øuch ≈øence in the Dutch, but ≈øignifies one that hath a ≈øharp wit to deceiue, as is ≈øaid of the ≈øerpent that beguiled Eue. Be≈øide, that that is tran≈ølated Emba≈ø≈øadour, ≈øpeaking of ≈øuch as were ≈øent
from the States to the King, I conceiue to be more fittingly rendred Me≈ø≈øenger.

Fir≈øt, thou art to vnder≈øtand, gentle Reader, that the King of Spaine was louingly receiued here in the 17 Prouinces, and a ≈øolemne oath was taken on both parts; the King for his part ≈øwore to maintaine all their Lawes and Priuiledges, and they to him all due homage and allgeance: Hee pre≈øently demanded of them a ≈øumme of money, whereupon the States did a≈ø≈øemble, and collected for him 40. millions of Florines, of Brabants money, to be paid in nine yeares, and paid it into his Exchequer; and although it was more then they had paid before to his predece≈ø≈øours, yet vpon this he did take great di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt them; and, as they write, he for this did hate them to death.

But he pretended this to be the cau≈øe of his wroth, becau≈øe he ≈øaw that there were ≈øome among them, that did defie the Pope and all his Religion: but that could not be, for the Citie of Ael≈øt was as ≈øuper≈øtitious in that Religion as Rome it ≈øelfe; for they did per≈øecute the Reformed Religion euen vnto death: and yet for all that both they, and 170 faire Villages that belonged vnto them, were by them plundered and ≈øpoyled of all their goods, and many of them wounded and tormented for to confe≈ø≈øe where their money was, and many were killed. Thus much by the way.

The mo≈øt ≈øacred Office of Inqui≈øition ≈øo often attempted in the Netherlands by his Maie≈øtie, and hindered vntill this time, ≈øhall be in≈øtituted and aduanced in this manner, which is mo≈øt expedient.
1 They mu≈øt per≈øwade the Emperour, being gone a≈øtray, and wickedly confederated with heretikes, that hee re≈øigne his Kingdomes vnto his Sonne, with the whole admini≈øtration of the Neitherlands.

2 That the Emperour with his two ≈øi≈øters, hauing giuen ouer all affaires, leauing the Netherlands, ≈øhall retire into Spaine vnto Vs, being a≈ø≈øured that they ≈øhall neuer returne more to doe any harme.
3 The≈øe being di≈øpatcht, we mu≈øt al≈øo draw the king to vs, and keepe him for euer that he part not, and not ≈øuffer any Flemmings to haue acce≈ø≈øe or conference with him.

4 That the King write vnto, and command the Clergie of the Netherlands that with the Inqui≈øition they ≈øhould accept of 15 new Bi≈øhops, the which ≈øhould be free from all ≈øecular iuri≈ødiction, yea in ca≈øes of trea≈øon.
5 The ≈øubiects of the Netherlands through their malice and waywardne≈ø≈øe, will reuolt and moue ≈øeditions and tumults, plea≈øing to all but to our companie.
6 The Princes and Noblemen, heads and authours of tho≈øe factions, with the ≈øubiects, mu≈øt be taken away, and the others reduced vnto rea≈øon.

7 They ≈øhall hire at our charge theeues and ≈øpoilers of Churches and Images, who≈øe offences ≈øhall be by all the world imputed to Rebels, by ≈øome ≈øubtill meanes, and ≈øo we ≈øhall vanqui≈øh them.
8 That all Comerce, Negotiation, Liberties and Priuiledges, ≈øhall be rooted out, and that all be reduced to extreame pouertie, whereby the realme ≈øhall be permanent for Vs.

9 No man of all tho≈øe Countries (except he be of our faction) ≈øhall be held worthy to liue; and finally all to be rooted out: and all Goods, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, Arts, and Trades, and all Orders to bee
taken away, vntill there may bee a new Realme, and a new people.

10 In this action the wi≈øe and valiant Duke Alva ≈øhal be imployed in per≈øon; whereas any other, were he of the bloud Royall, or a Prince, ≈øhall be of no e≈øteeme: ≈øo as being ≈øu≈øpect, yea in the ≈ømalle≈øt matters, they mu≈øt be di≈øpatcht.
11 No Contracts, Rights, Promi≈øes, Donations, Oathes, Priuiledges, and ≈øolemne A≈ø≈øertions of the Netherlands, ≈øhall be of any force for the Inhabitants, as being guilty of high trea≈øon.

12 But aboue al we mu≈øt haue an e≈øpeciall care that in the≈øe matters of ≈øo great weight and moment, wee proceed not violently, but by meanes, by degrees, and that di≈øcreetly, to the end the Princes, Nobilitie, and inferiour ≈øubiects may mutinie among≈øt them≈øelues, ≈øo that one may per≈øecute, yea execute the other vntill at la≈øt the hangman be executed him≈øelfe. For in all Chri≈øtendome is there not a Nation more fooli≈øh and indi≈øcreet, and who≈øe levitie and incon≈øtancy may ≈øooner be deceiued then the≈øe Netherlanders and God puni≈øheth them accordingly.
There were other Articles found in Pre≈øident Vergaes chamber at Antwerpe, and there Printed; and tho≈øe are more cruell then the≈øe.

By the≈øe articles and vnlimited power of the≈øe lawle≈ø≈øe Inqui≈øitors, no man had any a≈ø≈øurance of life or goods for a day, but were in danger continually to be called into que≈øtion, either for the law of their God, or for ≈øome work of mercie, which either religion, morall equitie, or the bond of nature called for: or el≈øe if they had colour for none of the≈øe, they would impo≈øe ≈øuch vnrea≈øonable taxations, which if the Cormorants had not their gorges crambed full, they would make prey of all, whether by right or wrong it mattered not. But my purpo≈øe being to auoid prolixitie, and to pa≈ø≈øe by impertinencies and needle≈ø≈øe repetitions, I will come to that I intended. In the yeare 1565, a match was concluded for the Prince of Parma, and the nuptials were ≈øolemnized at Bruxels, whither all the Nobilitie and Gentry of the Countrey were inuited, and accordinglyt, here met of them about foure hundred, who like faithfull Mo≈øes being grieued to ≈øee the daily oppre≈ø≈øion of their brethren by the hard task-ma≈øters of the Inqui≈øition, who not onely robbed them of
their goods, but al≈øo by inhumane crueltie, and vnnaturall butchery, depriued them of their liues, who daily led them as ≈øheepe vnto the ≈ølaughter: The con≈øideration hereof they ioyntly layd to heart, and hereupon (being met vpon this occa≈øion) they re≈øolued to pre≈øent a petition to the Prince≈ø≈øe of Parma, which they did the fifth of April next following. The Earle of Breedrod deliuering the petition, humbly reque≈øted a fauourable an≈øwer. Three dayes after they receiued this an≈øwer, viz. they ≈øhould ≈øend two of their Noblemen to the king, by whom ≈øhe would write in their behalfe. The Lord of Barlaymont being pre≈øent, after their departure ≈øaid (like a flattering Courtier) they were a company of Ra≈øcals and Beggars.
It was concluded that the Marque≈ø≈øe of Bargen, and the Lord of Mountigny ≈øhould goe into Spaine, who humbly pre≈øented their ≈øuit to the King, but could get no an≈øwer in 16 Moneths after.

The 26 of Augu≈øt anno 1566, the Prince≈ø≈øe of Parma ≈øent for the Gentrie, telling them ≈øhe had receiued letters from the King, containing promi≈øe that all ≈øhould be well, and that the Inqui≈øition ≈øhould cea≈øe. And for the Proclamations they ≈øhould not be of force, but his Maie≈øtie would take ≈øuch order as they and the State ≈øhould well like of. The Prince≈ø≈øe al≈øo gaue them toleration for their Religion, on condition, they ≈øhould not deface, nor breake downe the ornaments of the Churches: for, there had beene before this time vilde and lewde per≈øons that frequented the meetings of the Reformed; the≈øe went into the Papi≈øts Churches, ≈øtole their ≈øiluer and what was worth carrying away, and brake down their Images: but the Reformed ≈øu≈øpected that this was done by the appointment of the Prince≈ø≈øe; neither was their ≈øu≈øpition without good ground, for it is to be ≈øeene in the Kings letters, Art. 7. that ≈øhe had order to hire this raskall company to doe this villany, Emanuel de Miter ≈øaith, that in Flanders they tooke 50. of them at one time, and hanged 2 ‚Ä¢ , and whipped the re≈øt. which fact was imputed to the Prote≈øtants, to the end that they might not only be odious there, but al≈øo ≈øeeme guilty, euen in the iudgement of other Nations; howbeit the offenders were puni≈øhed with impri≈øonment, yea, with death, euen by the Reformed them≈øelues, who iointly confe≈ø≈øed the action vnlawfull, and were ≈øo farre from hauing occa≈øion of offence in this nature, that Papi≈øt Burgers them≈øelues offered good ≈øecuritie that no ≈øuch thing ≈øhould be attempted by them. Who then can make any doubt that they were free from giuing any hand in tho≈øe outrages laid to them, the very oppo≈øites in Religion
being Iudges, who as appeares were willing to undertake for them; now as their faithfulne≈ø≈øe brought ≈øo good effect for their per≈øons, ≈øo did the Lord worke that the truth of Religion found many friends likewi≈øe, the Lord wondrou≈øly pro≈øpering the cour≈øe of Reformation, in ≈øo much that in ≈øhort ≈øpace they had in Flanders 60 A≈ø≈øemblies, ≈øome Churches them≈øelues builded, but were by Duke d' Alva ≈øoone ca≈øt downe, who erected gallow≈øes of them, and hanged them vpon them.

The Prince≈ø≈øe of Parma al≈øo began to entertaine ≈øouldiers with pretence to apprehend the Church-robbers, but intended indeed to take away the ancient Liberties and Priuiledges of the Netherlanders, wherefore ≈øending certaine companies to Valencyn, the inhabitants denied them entertainment, who for that were proclaimed Rebels the 14 of December, ≈øoone after they were be≈øieged, ≈øacked, and many of them put to death.

But before they of Valencyn denied entertainment to the ≈øouldiers, Let pretended it for religion, but his aime was to get their lands and goods. the Nobility had receiued letters out of Spaine, from the Marque≈ø≈øe of Bargen, ≈øhewing, that the King was exceedingly incen≈øed again≈øt the Netherlanders, that he had in the pre≈øence of many vowed to be fully reuenged of them, though it were with the hazard of all his Countries; that hee would make them an example to all the world, and would inuite the Pope and Emperour to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in this quarrell. Vpon the receit of the letters the Nobility a≈ø≈øembled at Dortmond to con≈øult what were be≈øt to be done, but concluded not any thing, ≈øome iudging it ≈øafe≈øt to ioyne, and make head to re≈øi≈øt his tyrannicall furie, other ≈øeeking rather to e≈øcape by flight.

Now was the Inqui≈øition againe brought in contrary to the Lawes and Liberties of the Country, which the King was ≈øworne to maintaine, for execution whereof there were appointed 12. Inqui≈øitors, commaunding them to receiue the Councell of Trent, the≈øe were called, The bloudy Councell, and ≈øo they were indeede, which Rome well knew, refu≈øing it, anno 1559. when as they fell vpon the Inqui≈øitors hou≈øe, ≈øet it on fire, wounded the chiefe of them, brake open the pri≈øon, and ≈øet at liberty the captiues, and would haue burned a Cloy≈øter that belonged vnto them, had they not beene by faire meanes di≈ø≈øwaded by two Lords in the Citie, viz. Marc‚ñ™ Antonio Colunus, Iuli ‚Ä¢ Cae≈øar.

Likewi≈øe Venice, Naples and Millaine, though they be Papi≈øts, would not ≈øuffer it; the Marchants of Lisbon who are as ≈øuper≈øtitious in the Romi≈øh Religion as any in the world, yet they did offer the King two millions and a halfe, that they might not haue it in their parts.

Yet the cruelty of this Inqui≈øition did here encrea≈øe, and many ≈øouldiers came into the Countrey, that ≈øome of the Countrey for≈øooke their hou≈øes, and re≈øorted towards Freezland, and ≈øome did ≈øtay at home, and went to meete Duke Alva, and welcomed him into the Countrey, and ≈øhewed him all the kindne≈ø≈øe they could, As the Grais of Egmond, & the Grais of Horn, & many of the Gentry at Bru≈ø≈øels, 1568. but hee very ≈øhortly tooke off mo≈øt of their heads, ≈øo that hee did ≈øo terrifie the inhabitants, that there fled out of the Countries more then an hundred thou≈øand hou≈øholders, be≈øides many that were taken in flying, were taken and hanged, and all the≈øe had their goods confi≈øcated to the King.

The Prince of Orange, and the Earle of Bredrod, and fine Earles, eight Lords, and fifty Gentlemen, and they had ≈øome fine thou≈øand of Souldiers being in Free≈øland, but were mo≈øt ouerthrowne by the Duke of Alua his forces; ≈øo that they were driuen to Embden land, and there prepared them≈øelues to the ≈øea.

Now the Duke of Alua did commaund all the inhabitants to pay the hundreth peny of all their goods, and of all that was bought and ≈øold‚ñ™ the which ≈øome of the States did yeeld vnto: And then hee commaunded them to pay the twentith peny: and then hee commaunded the tenth peny of all things that were bought and ≈øold, ≈øo often as they ≈øhould be ≈øold. Some of the States did make their humble petition to the Duke, and to the Princes, ≈øhewing them that it would driue all trading out of the land. The Duke of Alua told them that hee would haue it, though it did ruinate all the land; but if hee ≈øaw them to doe their be≈øt to pay it, hee would deale fauourably with them. All the pri≈øons were filled, in ≈øo much as they were forced to prepare more, and filled them al≈øo. But hee ≈øaid that it was again≈øt the Kings honour if they ≈øhould not pay it, ≈øeeing it was his plea≈øure to require it. And now did the Inqui≈øition impri≈øon and execute many of the richer ≈øort, as well Papi≈øts as of the reformed Church: and if they were rich, there was no e≈øcaping for them. And who≈øoeuer was found to haue any hand in way of ≈øuit and petition to haue the tenth
peny to be remitted, they were adiudged to haue committed high trea≈øon again≈øt God and the King; and all the≈øe mu≈øt forfeit life and goods to the king, and not any of their children to enioy one peny worth of the ≈øame: but (poore Orphanes) they mu≈øt begge their bread. And ≈øome that had beene buried certaine months, they cau≈øed them to be digged vp, and hanged on the gallowes, and ≈øome to be burned, becau≈øe they had not the ≈øacrament, and confe≈ø≈øed before their death; but it was becau≈øe he would confi≈øcate their goods to the king: yea when the≈øe in≈øatiable gold-thir≈øty and bloud-thir≈øty wretches wanted colour to couer their iniu≈øtice and cruelty, they had their officious imps (fal≈øe-witne≈ø≈øes) ≈øuborned by Je≈øabel, to get Naboths vineyard; witne≈ø≈øe Marti ‚Ä¢ Hutton, who was one of the Inqui≈øitors Clarkes, and (being committed to Pri≈øon) did acknowledge that hee had made many fal≈øe te≈øtimonies again≈øt ≈øundry rich per≈øons, ≈øome whereof were of the reformed Church. Here might fitly be brought in the hundred Marchants of Granado, who were of the Romane Religion, and were neuer other; what pretence had hee to cau≈øe them to bee murthered all in one night, and then pre≈øently to command all their goods to be brought to his trea≈øurie of Exchequer, who≈øe e≈øtate was worth more then 28 hundred thou≈øand pounds ≈øterling? Now as this tyrant was a deuourer and de≈øtroyer of the liues of men, ≈øo did hee pre≈øume to v≈øurpe further, not only vpon ciuill ordinances, but vpon the things of God; ≈øo that tho≈øe that were married in the reformed Church, he forced to be married againe: and if they were rich, hee tooke them from their husbands, and gaue them to his ≈øouldiers to make prize of them. Tho≈øe that were baptized in the reformed Church, he compelled to be baptized againe, contrary to Gods word, and to the decree of the ancient coun≈øels, ≈øo that intolerable were the burthens this cruell Pharoh layd, ≈øo exce≈ø≈øiue was his cruelty, that he filled all places with blood, bloud touching bloud, as the Prophet ≈øpeakes. For in ≈ømall townes hee executed 50, and in great townes 200, and 300 or 400. And in places as men trauelled from one towne to another, they might ≈øee many that his ≈øouldiers had hung up in trees to death, and ≈øome were worth 80 thou≈øand guldens, and ≈øome le≈ø≈øe: yea, this tyrant did confi≈øcate ≈øo much lands and goods, as by his account ≈øent into Spain, did amount yearly to 8 tun of mony ≈øterling, be≈øides the many thou≈øands that he & his ≈øouldiers had.
All the money that he did exact out of this land in 6. yeares, did amount to more then 50. millions of gold. And if any were knowne to haue any thing that did belong to any that were put to death, and had not brought it to the knowledge of the Inqui≈øition, they did loo≈øe both life and goods: yea the 16. of February 1566. hee gaue ≈øentence in his Court at Madrill, that they were all traytors again≈øt God and him≈øelfe. At Vtrecht he beheaded a widow that was 84. yeares old, becau≈øe ≈øhee had before lodged a Preacher one night, who≈øe liuing was worth foure thou≈øand guldens yearely. And at Ma≈øtricht a father for lodging his ≈øon that he had not ≈øeene in a long time, that was fled for religion, was put to death. And at that place there was one put to death for giuing a widow a peck of corn for an almes, who≈øe husband this bloudy Court had put to death. And many women were put to death, becau≈øe they receiued their husbands in the night that were fled for religion; yea, they haue killed women great with child, and ripped vp their bellies, and taken out the child and killed it: and ≈øome they haue fleyed aliue, and couered drummes heads with their skies, and ≈øome they haue tyed to a po≈øt, and made a ≈ømall fire round about them, and ≈øo ro≈øted them to death.

At Naerden they receiued the Spaniards friendly into the towne, The like cruelty they did at Ondwater. who promi≈øed them both their liues and goods; and as ≈øoone as they came in, they commanded them to come to the State-hou≈øe without their Armes, the which they did, and the Spaniards gaue fire vpon them, and murthered them all: and then they ran about in the towne, and raui≈øhed the women, and after killed them and fired the towne. The yong children that lay in the cradle, they quartered them, and tooke them vpon their pikes, and ≈øo went vp and downe the towne, reioycing in their cruelty.

Such ≈øauage cruelty is ≈øcarcely to be found in any Hi≈øtory, what Chri≈øtian heart can heare it, and not be affected with deepe ≈øorrow, yet behold ≈øome mon≈øters herein haue been found, that haue beene ≈øo farre from humanity herein, (for hee that hath humanity in him will commi≈øerate others calamities) that they haue applauded it, as if he had in all the≈øe outrages done God good ≈øeruice. Among≈øt the re≈øt, I ≈øhall content my ≈øelfe at pre≈øent, but to name the holy Father the Pope, and one of his chiefe ≈øonnes in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe. The Pope ≈øends his Legate to commend the≈øe ≈øo rare exployts, and cals this cruell Duke Alua his beloued ≈øonne, ≈øends him a co≈øtly
≈øword, the hilts whereof were of Gold, and a hat wrought with gold, and be-≈øet with rich and co≈øtly ≈øtones, thanking him for his good ≈øeruice in maintaining the Romi≈øh Religion, and ≈øubuerting of heretikes. Howbeit that his chiefe ≈øon I mentioned (exceeding this man of ≈øin, in the ≈øin of cruelty, as if he would verifie him≈øelfe to be ten-fold more the child of Satan, then his father the Pope) thinkes not ≈øo well of it, his name is Vergas, the Pre≈øident of this bloudy Inqui≈øition; for going ≈øhortly after into Spaine, he told the King, that he and Duke d' Alua, did marre all in the Netherlands, by ≈øhewing ≈øo much mercy to tho≈øe people.

Concerning this Duke d' Alua, of who≈øe outrage and cruelty ≈øo many haue felt, and perfidious dealing which many haue found by lamentable experience, whereby may ea≈øily appeare of what ≈øtamp his exce≈ø≈øiue mercies are, euen ≈øuch as the Wi≈øeman ≈øpeakes of Pro. 12.10, the tender-mercies of the wicked are cruell. In which he prids him≈øelfe, The≈øe words he ≈øpake at a banquet, as he ≈øate at the Table, reioycing he had done the King ≈øo good ≈øeruice. boa≈øting he had ≈ølaughtered eighteen thou≈øand and ≈øixe hundred, in form of iu≈øtice, in ≈øix yeares times, and ten times ≈øo many he and his Souldiers murthered otherwaies. And many more would he doubtle≈ø≈øe haue murthered, had not the Lord re≈øtrayned and limited him, for his de≈øire herein was as hell, that cannot be ≈øatisfied: Witne≈ø≈øe the purpo≈øe of his proceeding again≈øt the Magi≈øtrates of Bruxels, becau≈øe they did not collect the tenth peny ≈øo as he de≈øired. He ≈øware that he would haue it, and before he would let it fall or remit it, the Sunne and Moone ≈øhould leaue their ≈øhining: ≈øo he went to Bru≈ø≈øels, and commanded the executioner to prepare ladders and ropes to hang vp that night in their doores 70 of the citizens, Anno 573 1 April. 1. I haue in≈øtanced but 4 or 5 towns, but there were ≈øcarce any town e≈øcaped their cruell pillaging, except they had bribed their Commanders with exceeding large „Äà‚óä„Äâ . and gaue them his warrant in writing what they ≈øhould be: But God in his prouidence preuented this his cruell purpo≈øe, in that there came newes that the Graue of Mark had taken in the Brill, ≈øo the tyrant did not goe forward with his bloudy enterpri≈øes.
